class_notes:
"For Want of Language" | Is there some hidden relation between desire and language? Each, it would seem, tries to recall something absent; each frequently gives way to fantasy; each seeks communion between self and other. The consequences of such a relation can already be glimpsed in the French verb "vouloir dire" (i.e., 'to mean'), which translates literally as "wanting to say," thus suggesting that language is perhaps not so much a carrier of meaning as a desire for it. From this perspective, our course will analyze how literary figures of desire open onto fundamental questions about language, meaning, and identity in general. Focusing especially (though not exclusively) on figures of romantic and sexual desire, we will interpret several works of literature and art using approaches borrowed from psychoanalysis, feminist and queer theory, structuralism, and deconstruction. Texts may include literary works by Ovid, Balzac, Rachilde, Wilde, Butler, Baldwin, and Mishima; films by Marcel Camus and Park Chan-Wook; and essays by Freud, Barthes, Derrida, Cixous, and Edelman.
